entry.title: Connect-Three
entry.content:
http://codeforces.com/contest/1087/problem/C

The Squareland national forest is divided into equal 1Ã—1 square plots aligned with north-south and east-west directions. Each plot can be uniquely described by integer Cartesian coordinates (ğ‘¥,ğ‘¦) of its south-west corner.

Three friends, Alice, Bob, and Charlie are going to buy three distinct plots of land ğ´,ğµ,ğ¶ in the forest. Initially, all plots in the forest (including the plots ğ´,ğµ,ğ¶) are covered by trees. The friends want to visit each other, so they want to clean some of the plots from trees. After cleaning, one should be able to reach any of the plots ğ´,ğµ,ğ¶ from any other one of those by moving through adjacent cleared plots. Two plots are adjacent if they share a side.

For example, ğ´=(0,0), ğµ=(1,1), ğ¶=(2,2). The minimal number of plots to be cleared is 5. One of the ways to do it is shown with the gray color.
Of course, the friends donâ€™t want to strain too much. Help them find out the smallest number of plots they need to clean from trees.

Input

The first line contains two integers ğ‘¥ğ´ and ğ‘¦ğ´ â€” coordinates of the plot ğ´ (0â‰¤ğ‘¥ğ´,ğ‘¦ğ´â‰¤1000). The following two lines describe coordinates (ğ‘¥ğµ,ğ‘¦ğµ) and (ğ‘¥ğ¶,ğ‘¦ğ¶) of plots ğµ and ğ¶ respectively in the same format (0â‰¤ğ‘¥ğµ,ğ‘¦ğµ,ğ‘¥ğ¶,ğ‘¦ğ¶â‰¤1000). It is guaranteed that all three plots are distinct.

Output

On the first line print a single integer ğ‘˜ â€” the smallest number of plots needed to be cleaned from trees. The following ğ‘˜ lines should contain coordinates of all plots needed to be cleaned. All ğ‘˜ plots should be distinct. You can output the plots in any order.

If there are multiple solutions, print any of them.

Examples

entry.title: T-shirt
entry.content:
æ—¶é—´é™åˆ¶: 1 Sec å†…å­˜é™åˆ¶: 64 MB

é¢˜ç›®æè¿°

JSZKC is going to spend his vacation!
His vacation has N days. Each day, he can choose a T-shirt to wear. Obviously, he doesnâ€™t want to wear a singer color T-shirt since others will consider he has worn one T-shirt all the time.
To avoid this problem, he has M different T-shirt with different color. If he wears A color T-shirt this day and B color T-shirt the next day, then he will get the pleasure of f[A][B].(notice: He is able to wear one T-shirt in two continuous days but may get a low pleasure)
Please calculate the max pleasure he can get.

è¾“å…¥

The input file contains several test cases, each of them as described below.
The first line of the input contains two integers N,M (2 â‰¤ Nâ‰¤ 100000, 1 â‰¤ Mâ‰¤ 100), giving the length of vacation and the T-shirts that JSZKC has.
The next follows M lines with each line M integers. The jth integer in the ith line means f[i][j](1<=f[i][j]<=1000000).
There are no more than 10 test cases.

è¾“å‡º

One line per case, an integer indicates the answer

entry.title: Polyline-Simplification
entry.content:
æ—¶é—´é™åˆ¶: 5 Sec å†…å­˜é™åˆ¶: 128 MB

é¢˜ç›®æè¿°

Mapping applications often represent the boundaries of countries, cities, etc. as polylines, which are connected sequences of line segments. Since fine details have to be shown when the user zooms into the map,these polylines often contain a very large number of segments. When the user zooms out, however, these fine details are not important and it is wasteful to process and draw the polylines with so many segments. In this problem, we consider a particular polyline simplification algorithm designed to approximate the original polyline with a polyline with fewer segments.
A polyline with n segments is described by n + 1 points p0 = (x0, y0),â€¦ , pn = (xn, yn), with the ith line segment being . The polyline can be simplified by removing an interior point pi (1â‰¤iâ‰¤n-1),so that the line segments are replaced by the line segment . To select the point to be removed, we examine the area of the triangle formed by pi-1, pi, and pi+1 (the area is 0 if the three points are colinear), and choose the point pi such that the area of the triangle is smallest. Ties are broken by choosing the point with the lowest index. This can be applied again to the resulting polyline, until the desired number m of line segments is reached.
Consider the example below.

The original polyline is shown at the top. The area of the triangle formed by p2, p3, and p4 is considered (middle), and p3 is removed if the area is the smallest among all such triangles. The resulting polyline after p3 is removed is shown at the bottom.

è¾“å…¥

The first line of input contains two integers n (2â‰¤nâ‰¤200 000) and m (1â‰¤m < n). The next n+1 lines specify p0,â€¦, pn. Each point is given by its x and y coordinates which are integers between -5000 and 5000 inclusive. You may assume that the given points are strictly increasing in lexicographical order. That is, xi < xi+1, or xi = xi+1 and yi < yi+1 for all 0â‰¤i < n.

è¾“å‡º

Print on the kth line the index of the point removed in the kth step of the algorithm described above (use the index in the original polyline).

æ ·ä¾‹è¾“å‡º

entry.title: å“¥å¾·å·´èµ«çŒœæƒ³
entry.content:
é¢˜ç›®é“¾æ¥ https://nanti.jisuanke.com/t/25985

Description:

Goldbachâ€™s conjecture is one of the oldest and best-known unsolved problems in number theory and all of mathematics. It states:

Every even integer greater than 2 can be expressed as the sum of two primes.

The actual verification of the Goldbach conjecture shows that even numbers below at least 1e14 can be expressed as a sum of two prime numbers.

Many times, there are more than one way to represent even numbers as two prime numbers.

For example, 18=5+13=7+11, 64=3+61=5+59=11+53=17+47=23+41, etc.

Now this problem is asking you to divide a postive even integer n (2<n<2^63) into two prime numbers.

Although a certain scope of the problem has not been strictly proved the correctness of Goldbachâ€™s conjecture, we still hope that you can solve it.

If you find that an even number of Goldbach conjectures are not true, then this question will be wrong, but we would like to congratulate you on solving this math problem that has plagued humanity for hundreds of years.

Input:

The first line of input is a T means the number of the cases.

Next T lines, each line is a postive even integer n (2<n<2^63).

Output:

The output is also T lines, each line is two number we asked for.

T is about 100.

entry.title: Hopscotch
entry.content:
æ—¶é—´é™åˆ¶: 5 Sec å†…å­˜é™åˆ¶: 128 MB

é¢˜ç›®æè¿°

Youâ€™re playing hopscotch! You start at the origin and your goal is to hop to the lattice point (N, N). A hop consists of going from lattice point (x1, y1) to (x2, y2), where x1 < x2 and y1 < y2.
You dislike making small hops though. Youâ€™ve decided that for every hop you make between two lattice points, the x-coordinate must increase by at least X and the y-coordinate must increase by at least Y .
Compute the number of distinct paths you can take between (0, 0) and (N, N) that respect the above constraints. Two paths are distinct if there is some lattice point that you visit in one path which you donâ€™t visit in the other.
Hint: The output involves arithmetic mod 109+ 7. Note that with p a prime like 109+ 7, and x an integer not equal to 0 mod p, then x(xpâˆ’2) mod p equals 1 mod p.

è¾“å…¥

The input consists of a line of three integers, N X Y . You may assume 1 â‰¤ X, Y â‰¤ N â‰¤ 106.

è¾“å‡º

The number of distinct paths you can take between the two lattice points can be very large. Hence output this number modulo 1 000 000 007 (109+ 7).

æ ·ä¾‹è¾“å…¥

æ ·ä¾‹è¾“å‡º

é¢˜è§£

é¢˜ç›®å¤§æ„: ç»™å®šä¸‰ä¸ªæ•°n,x,yã€‚è¡¨ç¤ºæœ‰ä¸€ä¸ªn*nçš„æ–¹é˜µï¼Œå¦‚æœx1+x<x2ä¸”y1+y<y2ï¼Œé‚£ä¹ˆå¯ä»¥ä»(x1,y1)è·³åˆ°(x2,y2)ï¼Œé—®ä»(0,0)è·³åˆ°(n,n)æœ‰å¤šå°‘ç§ä¸åŒçš„èµ°æ³•ã€‚
